stem: A 40-year-old client with a T3 spinal cord injury (SCI) is undergoing a scheduled bed change. Suddenly, their BP rises and they begin to shiver. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, two actions the nurse should take, and two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Severe hypertensive spike in a client with quadriplegia.
Background: T3 level complete SCI. Self-catheterizes (Bladder is currently empty).
Assessment: BP is 210/118. Client is extremely flushed on their face and chest.
Recommendation: Inspect for non-urological triggers.

tabs.title: Skin & Vascular Log
tabs.content:
AssessmentResultNotes
Sacral RegionStage 2 pressure injury foundDeep shear from bed transition
Shoes / SocksCompression socks are rolled tightActing like a tourniquet
Bladder Scan60 mLEmpty
Bowel SoundsActive; Last BM this AMUnlikely trigger

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 210/118, HR 52, RR 24. Client is reporting blurred vision.

actionOptions.text: Immediately elevate the head of the bed to 90 degrees.
Remove the restrictive socks and alleviate pressure on the sacral sore.
Instruct the client to cough vigorously to lower the BP.
Administer STAT IV Epinephrine to increase the heart rate.

parameterOptions.text: Frequent blood pressure and heart rate monitoring.
Visual changes and presence of a pounding headache.
Presence of a positive Babinski sign.

rationale.correct: This is Autonomic Dysreflexia (AD) triggered by skin-related noxious stimuli (Pressure injury and tight socks). Even though the bladder is empty, any painful/irritating stimulus below the level of injury (T3) will cause the sympathetic surge. Priority #1 is elevating the HOB (a1) to drop BP immediately. Priority #2 is removing the trigger (a2) (socks/pressure). Parameters focus on the BP spike (p1) and neurological symptoms of the hypertensive crisis (p2).
clinicalPearls: While a full bladder is the #1 trigger of AD, tight clothing, shoes, or a pressure sore are major contributors.
The 'Pounding Headache' is the classic subjective symptom of a dangerous AD spike.
Always loosen any tight clothing or straps if AD is suspected.

questionTrap.trap: Calling the provider before sitting the patient up.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Sitting the patient up (90 degrees) IS the treatment. If you wait to call the provider while the patient is flat, they might have a hemorrhagic stroke from the 210/118 pressure. Sit them up immediately.

mnemonic.title: AD Priority
mnemonic.expansion: 1. Sit UP. 2. Loosen CLOTHES. 3. Check BLADDER. 4. Notify DOC.
